thread.title: APRA boss Wayne Byres won't turn jail bird for 'Sugar' Rory Robertson
thread.title_full: APRA boss Wayne Byres won't turn jail bird for 'Sugar' Rory Robertson

author: CBD
title: APRA boss Wayne Byres won't turn jail bird for 'Sugar' Rory Robertson
text:
Illustration: John Shakespeare.
Westpac economist and anti-sugar crusader Rory Robertson was more than happy to sweet talk his fellow Reserve Bank alumni, APRA chair Wayne Byres , at a Sydney speech on Wednesday.
"I think that you and I were graduates together at the Reserve Bank in 1988, so congratulations on your massive outperformance," Robertson said to much laughter.
"I'm sure you are far wealthier than me," cracked Byres in reply.
Having softened up his former colleague, Robertson popped up a prickly question about NAB reclassifying billions of dollars worth of loans as housing investor rather than owner-occupied.
Advertisement Byres said he couldn't answer this directly because the law threatens him with two years' jail for talking about specific banks
"I'd much rather not do that ... even for you, Rory," he said.
Kiwis re-Joyce Here we were thinking that Virgin's John Borghetti was the great nemesis of Qantas boss Alan Joyce .
Boy, were we wrong.
Air New Zealand boss Christopher Luxon was happy to point out how his airline's splendid results on Wednesday took the shine off the rival announcement from the flying 'roo.
This was obviously helped by the fact that Air NZ isn't really competing against a national airline.
"In many ways you have got Qantas as Air Sydney rather than Air Australia," he said.
Was somebody a little miffed at Joyce's comments at his own magnificent results last week?
"Qantas this year with these results will make more than Virgin, Air New Zealand, Singapore Airlines and Etihad put together and that's the first time in our history that we've achieved that," Joyce said last Thursday.
"We've just had an investment-grade rating last week. Of 300 commercial airlines in the world, only 30 covered their cost of capital and only seven had an investment grade rating. Air New Zealand is among the top-three airlines in the world," was Luxon's warrior reply.
Maybe Luxon just needed to pick on another Aussie airline after Air NZ's local partner, Borghetti's Virgin, promised to make a profit his year.
Joyce, for his part, did not spend the day wimping​ out.
He was addressing a national delegates meeting of his other bete noir, the Australian Services Union.
Haven't they had some lovely things to say about the Qantas boss, and his immediate underlings, over the years.
Nagging doubts Former Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett is not backing Mark Latham , OK? In his latest scribble for the Murdoch press, he just defends Latham's right to be Mark Latham.
"If you don't like Latham – indeed, if you don't like me, or anyone else – switch off, turn the page. That is your right," Kennett said.
"I simply defend his right to express his views. And in our increasingly bland society, he is never boring."
Latham's inability to be boring has cost him jobs outside of the media sector even before the latest implosion.
This time last year, the boards of Thoroughbred Breeders Australia and Aushorse​ Marketing, overlooked our former Labor leader as the chief executive of both bodies in favour of CBD colleague Tom Reilly .
Waugh's pitch While the Australian cricket team was getting cremated on English soil, Steve Waugh was busy with a different pitch.
The cricketing legend and former Australian of the Year is an investor in nTouch​, a Melbourne-based "proximity marketing" startup, which has agreed to be acquired by ASX-listed anti-counterfeiting group YPB for $4.5 million worth of shares.
nTouch​ were a little shy about revealing just how much of an interest Waugh has in the operation.
New Jobs Former Telstra boss David Thodey really knows how to pick the plum roles.
He has now signed on as the man charged by NSW Premier Mike Baird with helping to create 150,000 new jobs over the next four years as the chair of Jobs for NSW.
Given the skill with which he shed employees at Telstra, they must figure it's as easy as reversing gears.
Thodey didn't seem phased either.
"I'm excited to lead the Jobs for NSW board and for the opportunity to work with the NSW government to deliver jobs across the state," he said.
The press release did not make it clear whether his new job will count towards the 150,000 target.
Got a tip? ckruger@fairfaxmedia.com.au
